BoJ Minutes from April 24th-25th meeting states that it will take time to reach 2% target and that it is appropriate to persistently continue with easing
content:
Says

  • Financial conditions in Japan remain highly accommodative.
  • Japan's economy had been on a moderate expanding trend although exports have shown weakness recently.
  • Most members shared view that medium to long-term inflation expectations were likely to gradually converge to 2%.
  • One member said BoJ should flexibly and decisively conduct additional easing if inflation momentum was lost, while another member said it was necessary to strengthen monetary easing at this point to achieve target as soon as possible.

PREVIEW: BoJ minutes from April 24th-25th meeting due at 0050BST/1850CDT/0750HKT
content:
The BoJ are to release the minutes from the January meeting, where the central bank kept policy unchanged with the bank rate kept at -0.1% and long-term yield target held at around 0.0% as expected, but slightly modified its forward guidance in which it states that it will keep very low interest rate levels for an extended period of time at least through around Spring 2020 vs. Prev. guidance of maintaining low rates for an "extended period".

BoJ Governor Kuroda stated that the modification to its forward guidance was intended to clarify the central bank’s stance of continuing monetary easing for the foreseeable future and that it is possible the time frame regarding the forward guidance may exceed Spring 2020. The BoJ also stated at the meeting it will relax terms and conditions for securities lending and will consider introduction of ETF lending facility, while it also noted that it will take longer than intended to achieve 2% target and risks to economic and price outlooks are skewed to the downside.

Furthermore, the previously released Summary of Opinions from April 24th-25th meeting stated that although it will take time to achieve price stability target, it is necessary to persistently continue current powerful monetary easing as the momentum toward 2% target is maintained, while the BoJ also had the opinion that while downside risks to overseas economies continue to warrant attention, the view that a pick-up is expected in the second half of this year is appropriate at this point.

Today’s release is not expected to impact markets as the reaction to the actual meeting was muted, and as the BoJ held a more recent meeting last week in which it continued to maintain its policy settings and guidance.

content:
ASIA-PAC

China is reportedly ready to work with the relevant sides in order to firmly uphold multilateralism as well as oppose both protectionism and unilateralism at the G20 Summit, according to reports citing senior officials in Beijing. (Xinhua)

China Global Times Editor highlighted challenges of US-China relations ahead of the G20 in which he suggested that the current atmosphere between China and the US is not good and that he has learned China's stance now is that it is holding constructive and positive attitude towards upcoming China-US summit but is also fully preparing for its failure and an escalating trade war. (Twitter)

 

COMMODITIES

Russian Energy Minister Novak stated that it is still too early to talk about extending the OPEC deal into H2 and that oil demand in Q3 and Q4 are still unclear. (Newswires)

IEA Executive Director Birol said the situation is the Middle East is worrisome and are ready to act in an appropriate way if there is physical disruption in the Middle East but added the impact on prices has been limited so far as US shale is capping upside. (Newswires)

Iran crude oil exports stood at 300k BPD in the first three weeks of June compared to 500k BPD in May, according to industry sources and Refinitiv data. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump signed an executive order putting strong sanctions on Iran including the Supreme Leader in response to the recent drone attack, while he stated that the US does not want conflict with Iran and would love to reach a deal with Iran. In related news, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said increased sanctions on Iran were in the works prior to the recent attack and that the new sanctions will lock up billions more in Iranian assets. Mnuchin also commented that Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif will be hit with sanctions later this week and that 8 senior commanders of Iran's Revolutionary Guard Corp will also be hit with sanctions. (Newswires/Twitter)

US President Trump questioned why the US protects the Strait of Hormuz for "zero compensation" and suggested that other countries should protect themselves, while he also asked why the US needs to be there when they are "the largest producer of energy". (Twitter)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said he had a great discussion today with UAE Official Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan in which they discussed the need to promote freedom of navigation in the Gulf. (Newswires)

US Senior State Department Official stated that the US are constructing a coalition with its allies in order to preserve navigational freedom within the Gulf under the 'Sentinel Programme' which will aid the monitoring of all shipping, while it noted that the programme is a proactive deterrence. (Newswires)

France, UK and Germany submitted a diplomatic demarche to Iran on 22 June, warning of consequences if it does not keep to its nuclear commitments, according to Diplomats. (Newswires_

Iran reportedly will not accept dialogue with the US while it is under the threat of sanctions, while its ambassador to the UN said the atmosphere for dialogue with the US is not ready yet and that the new US sanctions show that the US has no respect for international law and order. (Newswires)

Russian Deputy Foreign Minister said Russia and its allies will counteract US sanctions on Iran and that the US is deliberately raising tensions with Iran. (Tass/RIA)

 

US

Fed’s Kaplan (non-voter, dove) said it is wise to take time to consider if there is a need to change rates and that he is concerned adding monetary stimulus will contribute to the buildup of excesses and imbalances. Kaplan also commented that current interest rates are in the neighbourhood of neutral and that it is too early to judge whether trade and global growth uncertainties will hurt the US, while he added that downside risks to the US economy have increased. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) saw its PT cut at Moffett Nathanson, which said that search revenue growth is likely to slow. Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) was under pressure after news that the drug maker would divest its Otezla stake to clinch approval for its proposed merger with Celgene (CELG – which also moved lower). FedEx (FDX) shares moved lower after, less than a month after apologising for the misdirection of packages between Huawei offices, FedEx had to apologise for another mistake, on which it blamed an "operational error" due to compliance with US restrictions on business with Huawei Technologies. Carmax (KMX) moved lower after a downgraded to neutral from buy at Buckingham. Beauty names, including Ulta Beauty (ULTA) sunk on the news that Amazon is launching an Amazon Professional Beauty Store. Electronic Arts (EA) firmed after being added to the “best idea list” at Stephens. Micron Technologies (MU) moved higher, despite receiving a price target cut at Mizuho, and ahead of earnings this week. Deere & Co (DE) shares were buoyant after the co. was upgraded to buy from hold at Jefferies. Disney (DIS) was lower after Pixar’s Toy Story 4 film missed revenue expectations in its first weekend. United Technologies (UTX) moved higher after an upgrade at Cowen, which cites the recent 5% sell-off as an opportunity. Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) touched fresh record highs after Wedbush rated the co. "buy", citing sustained comp-sales growth. Gold names, including Barrick Gold (GOLD), were lifted as gold prices moved toward six-year highs. US banks, including Goldman Sachs (GS), Morgan Stanley (MS) and State Street (STT) performed well after they cleared the first hurdle of the Fed's stress test. Axalta (AXTA) was buoyant after on reports that Jana Partners had built a position in the co. S&P 500 -0.2% at 2945, NASDAQ-100 -0.1% at 7723, Dow Jones 0% at 26729.

The T-Plex traded range bound earlier on before gaining traction going into the US session, seeing it comfortably in the green for settlement. Participants are likely to be cautious on the loading up of risk ahead of the G-20 summit and the geopolitical noise in the background. Analysts note the rally was assisted by thin volume, in addition to a chunky 28k+ TYU9 block purchase by a hedge fund as the European session came to a close, which was accompanied by a 4k+ block sale of ultra longs seeing the curve steepen. At settlement, the belly of the curve saw the most action (5-year yield down by c. 5.5bps); spreads were mixed, with the 2s/5s flattening by over 1bps, whilst the 5s/10s steepened by c. 0.5bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 13+ ticks higher at 127-30.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 24th June 2019: Fresh Iran sanctions steal the limelight as markets move sideways ahead of G20
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equites flat, Treasuries up, Dollar flat, Crude mixed.
  • REAR VIEW: US President Trump implements fresh Iran sanctions; US & allies vow to protect freedom of navigation in the Gulf; Iran says no to dialogue with the US while threat of sanctions remains; Fed’s Kaplan advocates for patience
  • COMING UP: RBA’s Bullock; ECB’s de Guindos, Coeure; Fed’s Powell, Williams, Bostic, Barkin, Bullard; US Richmond Fed, API Crude Inventories.

 

* MIDDLE EAST: As expected, US President Trump signed an executive order to implement sanctions on top Iranian officials, including its Supreme Leader Khamenei; Treasury Secretary Mnuchin announced shortly afterwards that Iran’s Foreign Minister Zarif would be also be sanctioned later in the week, caveating that the some of the fresh sanctions were already in the works prior to the downing of the US drone. Iran’s UN Ambassador said later in response that Iran will not accept dialogue with the US while it is under the threat of sanctions and that the sanctions were disrespectful of international law and order. With the key shipping channel, the Strait of Hormuz, at risk from rising conflict, the US announced that it was building a coalition with its allies in order to preserve navigational freedom within the Gulf, named the 'Sentinel Programme', which will aid the US & Allies in having eyes on all shipping. The US State Department later confirmed the US would be sending some of its own ships to participate in the programme. President Trump has frequently made clear his aversion to conflict, he reiterated this in some tweets on Monday where he asked why the US protects the Strait of Hormuz for "zero compensation", stating that other countries should protect themselves; he also asked why the US needs to be there when they are "the largest producer of energy". This interjection by Trump appears to be a tactic in trying to reduce Iran's leverage by promoting the importance of US shale production in meeting US demands for crude. With the new sanctions on Iran, it is beginning to appear the US is now going head-to-head with Russia too, given that the Russian Deputy foreign Minister said that the Kremlin and its allies will counteract sanctions placed on Iran. Although the US is not alone in its efforts against the Iranian regime, given Iran’s regional opponents (e.g. Saudi/Israel/UAE), and certain European nations could well be preparing a move following reports that France, UK, and Germany submitted a diplomatic demarche to Iran on June 22nd, warning of consequences if it does not keep to its nuclear commitments; previous sources had suggested that Iran is already exceeding its enriched uranium caps, so if maintained, could result in a clampdown on both sides of the pond.

* FED: In what seemed to be a mild push back against the market, which is more than 100% priced for July rate cut, as well as against other Fed members who have already expressed the desire for rate cuts, Fed’s Kaplan said it would be wise to take time to consider if there is a need to change rates and that he is concerned that adding monetary stimulus will contribute to the build up of excesses and imbalances. He added that it is too early to judge whether trade & global growth uncertainties will hurt the US and that monthly job gains of 60,000 to 120,000 would mean 'strong' jobs market. However, he did concede that downside risks to the US economy have increase. He also noted that current interest rates are 'in the neighbourhood' of neutral.

* G20: Optimism remains ahead of this week’s G20 meeting (and the highly anticipated “extended” meeting between US President Trump and China President Xi. Although constructive noises have been made from both sides, the chances of a deal this week are slim, and talks are being framed as a step to get trade negotiations back on track. However, some desks are becoming more vocal, warning that a lack of truce at the meetings endangers the risk rally induced by the dovish pivots of the Fed and ECB. Additionally, SocGen’s analysts warn that the G20 meeting coincides with month-, quarter-, and half-year-end, when portfolio flows could generate unforeseen swings in FX and fixed income.

* CHINESE PRESS’ COMMENTARY: Chinese negotiators will be able to take a tougher line with the US, due to China’s economic resilience, though researchers warned not to go too far in retaliatory measures, since the objective was to bring the US back to the negotiating table, SCMP reported, citing researchers at a Chinese think tank. People’s Daily editorial stated that China has the strength and patience to withstand a trade war, and it could fight to the end if the US persists; the article called on US to show good faith, and take into account US concerns, saying that only equal dialogue can lead to a win/win situation.

* RBA: Governor Lowe overnight said the impact of rate cuts on the exchange rate channel is the most important element of the central bank’s monetary policy transmission channel; however, he argued that if all central banks are easing, there is no FX rate channel, and accordingly, we should not expect a boost to growth from lower rates. Lowe called for support from fiscal policy and structural reforms. 

* ISTANBUL ELECTIONS: The re-run of the Istanbul elections saw opposition CHP party’s Imamoglu beat President Erdogan’s AKP candidate Yildrim (again) by a margin of 54% vs 45% (this extended the vote gap to 800k vs 14k at the original vote); crucially, Yildrim conceded. “This is the best possible outcome from a market perspective,” TD Securities said, “however, the AKP and Erdogan still have a few aces up their sleeves and we warn against excessive enthusiasm,” noting that ‘judicial revenge’ could potentially be on the cards for Imamoglu, who has been accused of supporting Gulen, a scholar who has been accused of masterminding a coup attempt in 2016.

* ITALY: The EU will hold-off opening a new EDP measure against Italy over high debt levels, the FT reported. The bund/BTP spread narrowed to around 240bps, accordingly, before reversing these relative gains somewhat.

* GERMANY IFO: In line with expectations but continues to paint a challenging picture. The fall offsets the rebound seen recently, and the expectations sit at a four-month low, and mitigates some of the optimism around the rise in the current assessment. Manufacturing sentiment fell further. However, wholesale trade sentiment put in an encouraging rise.

* RBI: Deputy Governor Acharya reportedly quit six months early, Business Standard reported, citing “unavoidable personal reasons.” The departure is not a surprise, since Acharya has clashed with the government on issues of central bank independence in the past. “At the margin, the composition of the MPC will likely become incrementally more dovish, in our view, as Dr Acharya stood on the more hawkish side of the policy spectrum,” Nomura said, “For now, the focus shifts to Dr Acharya’s successor, the submission of Dr Bimal Jalan committee report on the RBI’s economic capital framework and the union budget on 5th July.”

* WTI FUTURES (Q9) SETTLES USD 0.47 HIGHER AT USD 57.90/BBL; BRENT FUTURES (Q9) SETTLE USD 0.34 LOWER AT USD 64.86/BBL: Crude markets got off on the front foot to start the week, before eventually drifting lower into settlement on Monday. Geopolitics was undoubtedly providing support to the crude complex, with the US launching new sanctions against top Iranian officials. Later in the session the US announced it was constructing a coalition with its allies in order to preserve navigational freedom within the Gulf, naming it the 'Sentinel Programme', which will aid the US & Allies in having eyes on all shipping; this eased some supply-risk related concerns, providing headwinds to oil prices, on top of some Trump tweets expressing concern about the US’ presence in the region. Demand concerns still lurk in the backdrop, especially over the prospect of no trade resolution emerging from the G20, but UBS feels this may be overdone. “While this would clearly have negative implications for oil demand, the pull-back from above USD 70 per barrel a month ago largely prices in growing caution on global growth, but not the growing risk to medium-term supply that results from the increasingly hard-line US stance on Iran.” Although the G20 outcome is also arguably tied to the supply picture, where Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak has put off further public comment until after the summit, analysts at Citi note: “This at least implies that action at the G20 – perhaps including any progress in US-China trade talks – could be the deciding factor in Russia’s willingness to continue limiting output. Or, perhaps it was simply a dodge.” Elsewhere in supply news flow, trade sources noted that Nigeria’s Qua Iboe crude stream is to export 9 cargoes in August, up from 6 originally planned in July. RBC’s thinks that crude buyers will seek other sources of crude, particular in the Atlantic Basin region (which Nigeria falls under), as supply out of the Strait of Hormuz is put at risk. Looking ahead to Tuesday’s API data, and Wednesday’s DOE data, the street expects to see crude stocks drawing by 2.9mln bbls this week, distillates are likely to build by 0.5mln bbls, and gasoline is seen building 0.2mln bbls; Genscape reportedly forecast a draw in Cushing stocks this week of 165k bbls.

* WEEK’S SUPPLY: This week, the US Treasury will auction USD 131bln of 2-year (USD 40bln, Tuesday), 5-year (USD 41boln, Wednesday), 7-year (USD 32bln, Thursday), as well as a 2-year FRN (USD 18bln, Wednesday). USD 72bln matures at the month-end settlement, implying USD 59bln of net cash will be raised, TD Securities says.

* PREVIEW: US to sell USD 40bln 2-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EDT: From a relative value perspective, the current 2-year note is lacking set up ahead of Tuesday’s auction, and trades rich on asset swap versus older 2s. “The auction is expected to benefit from dovish June FOMC meeting,” SocGen says, “similarly, our view for a modest steepening of the 2s10s curve led by the front-end should also support demand for the auction.” However, SocGen warns that dealer holdings in the 2-3-year sector has risen to a record high, which might limit demand from dealers, and will need support from investment funds and foreign participants in order to perform well. Last month’s auction was well received against the backdrop of global trade wars, and the demand from the foreign and investment bid was solid. SocGen is positive on the 2s auction.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 13+ TICKS HIGHER AT 127-30: The T-Plex traded range bound earlier on before gaining traction going into the US session, seeing it comfortably in the green for settlement. Participants are likely to be cautious on the loading up of risk ahead of the G-20 summit and the geopolitical noise in the background. Analysts note the rally was assisted by thin volume, in addition to a chunky 28k+ TYU9 block purchase by a hedge fund as the European session came to a close, which was accompanied by a 4k+ block sale of ultra longs seeing the curve steepen. At settlement, the belly of the curve saw the most action (5-year yield down by c. 5.5bps); spreads were mixed, with the 2s/5s flattening by over 1bps, whilst the 5s/10s steepened by c. 0.5bps. 

* S&P 500 -0.2% at 2945, NASDAQ-100 -0.1% at 7723, Dow Jones 0% at 26729, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.5%, Consumer Staples 0.3%, Energy -0.9%, Financials -0.3%, Health Care -0.5%, Industrials -0.2%, Information Technology 0.2%, Materials 0.5%, Telecommunication Services 0.1%, Utilities  0%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) saw its PT cut at Moffett Nathanson, which said that search revenue growth is likely to slow. Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) was under pressure after news that the drug maker would divest its Otezla stake to clinch approval for its proposed merger with Celgene (CELG – which also moved lower). FedEx (FDX) shares moved lower after, less than a month after apologising for the misdirection of packages between Huawei offices, FedEx had to apologise for another mistake, on which it blamed an "operational error" due to compliance with US restrictions on business with Huawei Technologies. Carmax (KMX) moved lower after a downgraded to neutral from buy at Buckingham. Beauty names, including Ulta Beauty (ULTA) sunk on the news that Amazon is launching an Amazon Professional Beauty Store. Electronic Arts (EA) firmed after being added to the “best idea list” at Stephens. Micron Technologies (MU) moved higher, despite receiving a price target cut at Mizuho, and ahead of earnings this week. Deere & Co (DE) shares were buoyant after the co. was upgraded to buy from hold at Jefferies. Disney (DIS) was lower after Pixar’s Toy Story 4 film missed revenue expectations in its first weekend. United Technologies (UTX) moved higher after an upgrade at Cowen, which cites the recent 5% sell-off as an opportunity. Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) touched fresh record highs after Wedbush rated the co. "buy", citing sustained comp-sales growth. Gold names, including Barrick Gold (GOLD), were lifted as gold prices moved toward six-year highs. US banks, including Goldman Sachs (GS), Morgan Stanley (MS) and State Street (STT) performed well after they cleared the first hurdle of the Fed's stress test. Axalta (AXTA) was buoyant after on reports that Jana Partners had built a position in the co.

* FX WRAP: The risk on currencies (AUD, TRY and KRW) are performing well, the cyclical currencies (EUR, SEK) are up, and havens are mixed; the JPY has resumed settling into a thin range, after the slide post FOMC last Wednesday, the CHF is actually firmer, as is XAU, though DXY trades slightly negative; desks have noted that month-end factors may be playing a role (favours USD selling). Additionally, it may be that traders are focussing on the end of week risk events (G20, month/quarter/H1 end). A abysmal Dallas Fed headline led to some negative ticks for the buck, though the forward looking components were more encouraging (like the Empire and Philly Fed manufacturing surveys); the buck did little to suggest it was going to test its 200dma, which it slipped beneath last week, and is consolidating above 96.00. This weakness has allowed EUR to see upside, though 1.14 seems a touch level to negotiate. There was further upside for gold, and from a technical perspective, it will be interesting to see if it can close above the USD 1400 mark on a monthly candle, which would be a bullish sign, technicians argue. Antipodeans were firmer against the Buck, with the Aussie marginally eclipsing its neighbour in wake of comments from RBA’s Lowe overnight, who suggested that rate cuts become less effective if other global Central Banks are also in easing mode. AUDUSD is hovering near recent/today’s highs at 0.6960, while NZDUSD and the AUDNZD cross sit just above 0.6600 and 1.0500 respectively ahead of Wednesday’s RBNZ.

* USD: After breaching its 200dma last week, the DXY continues to slide. Technicians note that the breach has occurred three times thus far in 2019, with each proving to be a buying opportunity. The question is whether the Fed looseness, risk-off (either due to threats to global growth, or even geopolitical escalation with Iran) dominates the narrative. A positive outcome at the G20 would make any rebound above the 200dma more challenging, analysts suggest. It is also worth noting that Barclays’ month-end FX rebalancing model favours strong USD selling.

* JPY, CHF: SocGen has warned that a lack of truce at the meetings endangers the risk rally induced by the dovish pivots of the Fed and ECB, and while JPY and CHF’s correlations to stocks and the CNY/CNH spread have lessened, the bank states that we could soon be close to levels where intervention by all three of the BOJ, SNB and PBOC becomes a risk; fallout from the G20 may provide the catalyst.

* TRY: Initially rallied after CHP edge out Erdogan’s AKP in the Istanbul election re-run, though desks have warned against excessive optimism and USDTRY has since erased the weekend’s losses.

* BRL: Was firmer amid optimism ahead of the potential Brazilian pension reform vote with O Globo suggesting that the bill has the support of around 318 parliamentarians (308 required). In terms of timing for the vote, UBS notes there is still optimism for a vote on June 26th despite comments from President Bolsonaro that the vote could be delayed by a week. UBS also highlight that a deal could be brokered by the Lower House speaker Maia that would see the vote take place before the July 17th recess.

• The risk on currencies (AUD, TRY and KRW) are performing well, the cyclical currencies (EUR, SEK) are up, and havens are mixed; the JPY has resumed settling into a thin range, after the slide post FOMC last Wednesday, the CHF is actually firmer, as is XAU, though DXY trades slightly negative; desks have noted that month-end factors may be playing a role (favours USD selling). Additionally, it may be that traders are focussing on the end of week risk events (G20, month/quarter/H1 end). A abysmal Dallas Fed headline led to some negative ticks for the buck, though the forward looking components were more encouraging (like the Empire and Philly Fed manufacturing surveys); the buck did little to suggest it was going to test its 200dma, which it slipped beneath last week, and is consolidating above 96.00. This weakness has allowed EUR to see upside, though 1.14 seems a touch level to negotiate. There was further upside for gold, and from a technical perspective, it will be interesting to see if it can close above the USD 1400 mark on a monthly candle, which would be a bullish sign, technicians argue. Antipodeans were firmer against the Buck, with the Aussie marginally eclipsing its neighbour in wake of comments from RBA’s Lowe overnight, who suggested that rate cuts become less effective if other global Central Banks are also in easing mode. AUDUSD is hovering near recent/today’s highs at 0.6960, while NZDUSD and the AUDNZD cross sit just above 0.6600 and 1.0500 respectively ahead of Wednesday’s RBNZ.
  • * USD: After breaching its 200dma last week, the DXY continues to slide. Technicians note that the breach has occurred three times thus far in 2019, with each proving to be a buying opportunity. The question is whether the Fed looseness, risk-off (either due to threats to global growth, or even geopolitical escalation with Iran) dominates the narrative. A positive outcome at the G20 would make any rebound above the 200dma more challenging, analysts suggest. It is also worth noting that Barclays’ month-end FX rebalancing model favours strong USD selling.
  • * JPY, CHF: SocGen has warned that a lack of truce at the meetings endangers the risk rally induced by the dovish pivots of the Fed and ECB, and while JPY and CHF’s correlations to stocks and the CNY/CNH spread have lessened, the bank states that we could soon be close to levels where intervention by all three of the BOJ, SNB and PBOC becomes a risk; fallout from the G20 may provide the catalyst.
  • * TRY: Rallied after CHP edge out Erdogan’s AKP in the Istanbul election re-run, though desks have warned against excessive optimism.
  • * BRL: Was firmer amid optimism ahead of the potential Brazilian pension reform vote with O Globo suggesting that the bill has the support of around 318 parliamentarians (308 required). In terms of timing for the vote, UBS notes there is still optimism for a vote on June 26th despite comments from President Bolsonaro that the vote could be delayed by a week. UBS also highlight that a deal could be brokered by the Lower House speaker Maia that would see the vote take place before the July 17th recess.

analysis_details: Crude markets got off on the front foot to start the week, before eventually drifting lower into settlement on Monday. Geopolitics was undoubtedly providing support to the crude complex, with the US launching new sanctions against top Iranian officials. Later in the session the US announced it was constructing a coalition with its allies in order to preserve navigational freedom within the Gulf, naming it the 'Sentinel Programme', which will aid the US & Allies in having eyes on all shipping; this eased some supply-risk related concerns, providing headwinds to oil prices, on top of some Trump tweets expressing concern about the US’ presence in the region. Demand concerns still lurk in the backdrop, especially over the prospect of no trade resolution emerging from the G20, but UBS feels this may be overdone. “While this would clearly have negative implications for oil demand, the pull-back from above USD 70 per barrel a month ago largely prices in growing caution on global growth, but not the growing risk to medium-term supply that results from the increasingly hard-line US stance on Iran.” Although the G20 outcome is also arguably tied to the supply picture, where Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak has put off further public comment until after the summit, analysts at Citi note: “This at least implies that action at the G20 – perhaps including any progress in US-China trade talks – could be the deciding factor in Russia’s willingness to continue limiting output. Or, perhaps it was simply a dodge.” Elsewhere in supply news flow, trade sources noted that Nigeria’s Qua Iboe crude stream is to export 9 cargoes in August, up from 6 originally planned in July. RBC’s thinks that crude buyers will seek other sources of crude, particular in the Atlantic Basin region (which Nigeria falls under), as supply out of the Strait of Hormuz is put at risk. Looking ahead to Tuesday’s API data, and Wednesday’s DOE data, the street expects to see crude stocks drawing by 2.9mln bbls this week, distillates are likely to build by 0.5mln bbls, and gasoline is seen building 0.2mln bbls; Genscape reportedly forecast a draw in Cushing stocks this week of 165k bbls.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Buck bases, as Aussie outpaces and Pound flounders
content:
DXY

The index and broad Dollar have regained some composure despite the FOMC’s dovish twist and ongoing US-China/global trade and geopolitical jitters ahead of the G20. Moreover, month, quarter and half year end factors are also unsupportive as Barclays early indications point to strong selling for portfolio rebalancing. However, the DXY appears to have survived a sub-96.000 test with the help of technical support just below the big figure in the form of the 200 WMA (95.964) and as several rival currencies weaken more than Greenback or pare best gains.

JPY/GBP/NOK

The major underperformers, as the Yen crossed the NY cut bang on 1.3 bn option expiries at 107.50, albeit just and with minimal follow-through buying after holding around Fib support earlier (107.27), while Cable retreated from technical resistance to probe a similar downside chart level ahead of 1.2700 within a 1.2766-09 range (Fibs at 1.2766 and 1.2705) and the Pound also lost ground vs the Euro from circa 0.8920 to 0.8950+. Elsewhere, a retreat in oil prices weighed on the Norwegian Krona as Eur/Nok climbed from around 9.6500 to 9.6860 at one stage, in contrast to Eur/Sek that eased from just shy of 10.6400 to a fraction off 10.5925. Note, the Swedish Crown may have gleaned some traction from an MS trade of the week eyeing 10.2500 in the cross, although a Usd/Mxn short from the same bank targeting 18.2500 has moved in the opposite direction thus far.

AUD/NZD/CHF/EUR/CAD

All firmer against the Buck, as the Aussie also marginally eclipses its Antipodean peer in wake of comments from RBA’s Lowe overnight noting that rate cuts become less effective if other global Central Banks are also in easing mode. Aud/Usd is hovering near the upper end of 0.6929-61 trading parameters, while Nzd/Usd and the Aud/Nzd cross sit just above 0.6600 and 1.0500 respectively ahead of Wednesday’s RBNZ – for a detailed preview of the policy meeting see the Research Suite, but in short benchmark rates are forecast to remain unchanged before another ease in August. Elsewhere, the Franc has now breached resistance at 0.9750 and 1.1100 against the Euro that got closer to 1.1400 vs the Dollar, but held agonisingly below and is now revisiting the 50 DMA at 1.1390 which could be pivotal on a closing basis. The Loonie was also undermined by the aforementioned downturn in crude and retreated from circa 1.3178 to 1.3220 before paring back and awaiting the BoC’s regional survey for some independent impetus.

EM 

The Try has been volatile after early euphoria following the weekend Istanbul rerun and an overwhelming victory for the opposition was compounded by a relatively upbeat Turkish manufacturing survey, as broader weakness in the region vs the Usd permeated. However, the Lira remains firm within a circa 5.8300-7085 band unlike the Rand that is still reviewing last week’s SA SONA and mulling how President Ramaphosa aims to fund fresh aid pledged to Eskom and whether this will fall short of the cash needed to sort the company’s financial issues again. Usd/Zar is currently around 14.3575 within a 14.2365-40000 range vs Usd/Brl contained between 3.8075-8375 amidst more positive developments on the Brazil pension reform bill (various local press reports suggest enough votes to pass and maybe before mid-July).

RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 24th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

The first round of the Fed’s stress test results showed that all 18 banks examined are able to withstand an economic shock. The second and final round next week determines whether firms can win approval to boost capital pay-outs. Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) reportedly improved on last year’s poor results, adding to hope that they will escape limits on dividends and stock buybacks imposed back then.

DOW

  • Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) is mulling the sale of all of its oil and gas fields holdings off the Norwegian coast, although no decision has yet been made.
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) reportedly does not allow its employees to use Slack (WORK), who recently went public, reported GeekWire. In favour of their own workplace chat app, Microsoft Teams. The company cited security risks as the reason for the ban on Slack.
  • United Technologies (UTX) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) has had its price target raised to USD 150 from USD 135 at Cowen, who cite a potential “win-win” since the co.’s share price fell 5% in the aftermath of the announcement of the Raytheon Co. (RTN) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) merger.
  • The Walt Disney Company (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) Pixar’s Toy Story 4 film made USD 118 in total sales in its opening weekend, falling short of analyst expectations for USD 150mln.

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is reportedly exploring the use of drones to provide surveillance services.
  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services), Alphabet Inc. (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services), Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) - Senators Warner and Hawley are set to introduce legislation on Monday that would require tech companies such as Facebook, Google and Amazon to disclose the value of their users' data.
  • Kraft Heinz Co (KHC) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) has had its price target cut to USD 29 from USD 32 at Guggenheim, who say the company is in “dire” need of investment and after the company's fourth-quarter earnings missed expectations.
  • Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) had its profit target cut at Mizuho to USD 44 from USD 47, who cite the Huawei recent ban and weaker demand for handsets.
  • Nvidia Corporation (NVDA) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) have had their profit target cut at Susquehanna to USD 190 from USD 215, who cite Chinese efforts to accelerate its "self-sufficiency" program in the aftermath of the Huawei ban, which implies order cuts for the company.

S&P 500

  • Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) (Health Care/Health Care Distributors) plans the divesture of Otezla as it seeks FTC clearance to merge with Celgene Corp. (CELG) (Health Care/Biotechnology), however, the merger will be delayed until the end of 2019/beginning of 2020. Elsewhere, BMY’s CheckMate -459 study, evaluating the effectiveness of a late-stage cancer treatment, did not meet its pre-specified primary endpoints.
  • FedEx Corporation (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) - Less than a month after apologising for the misdirection of packages between Huawei offices, FedEx has had to apologise for another mistake, on which it blamed an "operational error" due to compliance with US restrictions on business with Huawei Technologies.
  • General Electric (GE) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) is planning to demolish a large California power plant after only one-third of its useful life, with the plant apparently no longer economically viable.
  • Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd (RCL) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines) is teaming up with ITM Group to form a new destination company called Holistica, in a 50/50 partnership.
  • AutoZone Inc (AZO) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Stores) has been hit with a USD 11mln charge over malpractice regarding toxic waste disposal.

OTHER

  • Axalta Coating (AXTA) (Materials/Chemicals) - Jana Partners have reportedly built a position in Axalta Coating.
  • Daimler (DAI GY) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) – Co. cut its 2019 outlook, citing costs in regard to the diesel emission scandal. Co. said it’s numbers will be hit by “a high three-digit million” charge and now expects its EBIT to be similar to last year’s level vs. Prev. guidance of “slightly higher” EBIT. The new outlook is EUR 500mln below current analysts’ consensus for 2019, according to data by S&P Global Market Intelligence. For reference, this is Co’s third profit warning in the last 12 months. Separately, German Transportation Minister stated that Co. must recall 60k Mercedes diesel cars in Germany after they were found to be fitted with software aimed at distorting emission tests.
  • Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) (Financials/Diversified Banks) – Fed officials have asked senior executives at the co. to explain ‘bad bank’ proposals, in order to explain concerns regarding a potential significant impact to the Co’s US operations. The size of such a scheme is still being decided, but executives are reportedly considering placing up to EUR 50bln of assets into it.
  • Eldorado Resorts (ERI) (Consumer Discretionary/Casinos & Gaming) and Caesars (CZR) (Consumer Discretionary/Casinos & Gaming) have announced a merger agreement. Eldorado will acquire all outstanding Caesars shares for USD 12.75 per share, an approximate total of USD 17.3bln, comprised of USD 7.2bln in cash, approximately 77M Eldorado common shares and the assumption of Caesars outstanding net debt.
  • Renault (RNO FP) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) is hoping to resume dialogue with Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) on a merger soon, according to reports.
  • Spotify Technology SA (SPOT) (Communication Services/Entertainment) has had its rating cut to underperform from in line at Evercore ISI, who cite competition as increasingly aggressive at the country level while Evercore see the company's data services and podcast as reaping only modest benefits.

content: Contacts note some big block trades in Eurodollars as the post-FOMC fall-out continues. In Sep19, a huge upside punt or hedge saw the 98.125/98.250/98.375 call butterfly bought for 2.5 ticks in 50k lots vs 98.015 in the underlying future with a 6% delta, while in contrast the 97.625/97.875 call spread was sold 25k times vs 98.025 at 20.5 ticks, delta 20% and the 97.750/97.875 1:2 call spread was sold at -10.5 ticks (ie premium cost) in the same size and reference, 57% delta. Elsewhere, the Jul19 97.875/98.000 call spread and Aug19 98.000 calls were sold as a strip vs 98.025 at 20 ticks in 10k lots, delta 78%.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 24th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • A choppy start to a potentially pivotally week for global trade [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.4%], with Trump & Xi due to meet at the G20 summit
  • US President Trump has stated that they will move ahead with additional sanctions on Iran; Iran’s Navy Commander said the downing of a US Spy drone was a ‘firm response’ and can be repeated
  • In FX, the USD remains subdued with Antipodeans leading G10 gains; while the TRY has rebounded post Istanbul election re-run
  • Looking ahead, highlights include NZ Trade, ECB’s Lautenschlager, Fed’s Harker

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week somewhat choppy with participants tentative ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting at the G20 this week and following the mild pullback last Friday on Wall St where all majors ended slightly lower on the day, but still notched gains of more than 2% for the week. ASX 200 (+0.2%) was initially led lower by underperformance in Consumer Staples and as comments from RBA Governor Lowe appeared to question the impact easing could have on the economy, while a non-committal tone was seen in the Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) amid a mixed currency. Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were indecisive after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and as global markets await the latest developments in the trade war saga including the Trump-Xi showdown this week, while the US recently added 5 Chinese entities to its blacklist barring them from buying US parts without government approval. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued with after recent similar moves in T-notes and as yields bounced back from multi-year lows, while demand was also dampened after stocks in Tokyo pared opening weakness and amid the absence of the BoJ in the market.  

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8503 (Prev. 6.8472)

China Vice Commerce Minister Wang Shouwen said China and US trade teams are having discussions, while he added that both sides should make compromises and hopes G20 sends a clear signal on fighting against trade protectionism. (Newswires)

China Vice Finance Minister Zou Jiayi has been appointed as a PBoC MPC member, according to China State Council. (Newswires)

China Assistant Foreign Minister Zhang Jun said the world economy faces increasing risks and the international community recognizes harm from protectionism, while he added that G20 should ensure unity and cooperation but also stated that China will safeguard its fundamental interests and will not allow anyone to interfere with its internal affairs no matter what forum. (Newswires)

US

Fed stress test results on Friday showed all banks exceeded minimum capital requirements and at strong levels that would allow them to remain above minimum required level after being tested against a severe hypothetical recession scenario. (Newswires)

China Foreign Ministry says that Fedex (FDX) should present a full explanation over the Huawei matter. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump also said that they are moving ahead with additional sanctions on Iran aimed at preventing it from getting a nuclear weapon and that military action is still on the table, while other reports also noted the White House is pressing for additional options including in cyberspace and other additional clandestine plans to counter Iranian aggression in the Persian Gulf. (Newswires/NYTimes) Subsequently, Iranian Navy Commander says the downing of the US Spy drone was a "firm response" and can be repeated, according to Tasmin News. (Newswires)

Russian Deputy Foreign Minister says Russia and allies will counteract US sanctions on Iran. Additionally, Russia’s Deputy Foreign Minister stated that ther US is deliberately increasing tensions with Iran. (Tass/Ria)

US President Trump administration’s Middle East peace plan reportedly proposes USD 50bln investment in Palestinian territories, Egypt, Jordan and Lebanon. Subsequently, Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman says US' Middle East peace plan is "shameful" and "doomed to failure", according to Fars News. (Newswires/Fars)

Iran said it believes EU lacks the will to salvage the multinational 2015 nuclear deal, while its Deputy Foreign Minister said the decision to decrease its commitment to nuclear deal is a national decision and irreversible as long as its demands are not met. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia’s Abha civilian airport located in the south of the country was attacked by Yemen's Houthi rebels which killed one person and wounded seven others, while the Arab Coalition stated that the attack by the Iranian-backed terrorist Houthi militia and the targeting of civilians is a brutal terrorist act. (Newswires)

North Korea confirmed that its leader Kim received a letter from US President Trump in which the contents of the letter were described as excellent. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

Conservative Party is reportedly making plans that would permit the next PM to hold off from putting their Brexit plans to Parliament until Autumn which could limit the time to reach a deal to just over 3 weeks before October 31st. (Independent)

Conservative leadership hopeful Hunt has accused Boris Johnson of being a coward for avoiding public scrutiny as pressure mounts on the Tory frontrunner to address the row with his girlfriend that led to police being called. (Times)

EY ITEM Club forecasts 2019 UK GDP growth at 1.3% Y/Y, sees consumer spending growth at 1.6% which is the slowest since 2013. (Newswires)

German Ifo Business Climate New (Jun) 97.4 vs. Exp. 97.2 (Prev. 97.9)

- German Ifo Curr Conditions New (Jun) 100.8 vs. Exp. 100.2 (Prev. 100.6, Rev. 100.7)

- German Ifo Expectations New (Jun) 94.2 vs. Exp. 94.5 (Prev. 95.3, Rev. 95.2)

- IFO state that the economy is heading toward the doldrums, though they maintain their GDP outlook and do not forsee a recession adding that the US-China conflict is currently the main source of uncertainty.

EQUITIES

A choppy day for European equities thus far [Eurostoxx 50 -0.4%] following on from a similar Asia-Pac session as markets await the Trump-Xi showdown later this week. Major bourses are mostly in the red, losses for the DAX (-0.5%) stem from declining auto names after Daimler (-4.7%) issued its third profit warning in 12 months, citing losses caused by the diesel emission scandal; hence, Volkswagen (-1.2%) and BMW (-1.2%) have fallen in sympathy. Sectors are also lower with consumer discretionary names pressured by Daimler’s profit warning. In terms of individual movers, Leonardo (+2.4%) shares spiked higher at the open amid speculation that the Co. is considering bidding for Maxar Technologies’ space robotics business, which sources state could be valued over USD 1bln. Meanwhile, Carrefour (+1.6%) shares are underpinned after it reached an agreement to sell 80% of its Chinese operations with the transaction representing an enterprise value of EUR 1.4bln. Finally, Morphosys (+7.2%) shares are bolstered amid news that a treatments primary endpoint was met.

US companies are looking for legal loopholes to help avoid or reduce duties without shifting production amid the US-China trade war. (FT)

FX

USD - The Greenback has fallen further following last week’s dovish Fed policy meeting and Friday’s relatively weak PMIs, with the DXY faltering after a fleeting attempt to pare losses and probe above 96.200. The 96.000 handle looks under threat and could be relinquished amidst strength elsewhere, with Gold edging back over Usd 1400/oz and Eur/Usd eyeing 1.1400. Note also, the pressure could build as the week unfolds with at least one currency rebalancing model flagging a strong sell signal for the end of June, Q2 and H1, not to mention the G20 where US President Trump is due to meet his Chinese counterpart Xi for extensive trade talks.

NZD/AUD - Perhaps surprisingly given ongoing global trade and geopolitical uncertainty, the Antipodean Dollars are outperforming major peers, or rather deriving most momentum from their US rival’s demise. The Kiwi is pivoting 0.6600 and Aussie 0.6950 ahead of this week’s RBNZ meeting on Wednesday with rates widely tipped to remain unchanged before another cut in August, while comments from RBA’s Lowe may have dampened some dovish expectations as he questioned the effectiveness of easing to support the economy in the context of moves by other Central Banks aimed at sustaining growth and reaching inflation targets.

CAD/EUR - The next best G10 currencies, as the Loonie consolidates recovery gains through 1.3200 after its post-Canadian retail sales wobble, with some support from firmer crude prices, and the Euro draws encouragement from the latest German Ifo survey that was not as weak as forecast overall. Moreover, the institute maintained its 2019 GDP estimate and played down the prospect of a recession even though the economy is in the doldrums, or heading that way. However, Eur/Usd has tested the 50 DMA (1.1390) after clearing 200 DMA and WMAs, but falling just short barriers at the next big figure where the top end of 2 bn option expiries lie (from 1.1390 coincidentally).

CHF/GBP/JPY - All narrowly mixed vs the Buck as the Franc stalls ahead of 0.9750 and Pound meets resistance above 1.2750 in the form of a 38.2% retracement of the fall from 1.3185 to 1.2506 at 1.2766. Meanwhile, the Yen has retreated a bit further from 107.00 and into a 107.29-48 band with technical support seen a fraction under (107.27 Fib) and decent expiry interest a whisker above (1.3 bn at the 107.50 strike).

EM - The Lira has rebounded further from recent lows and in large part on the back of a resounding result at the 2nd Istanbul election that will not be contested this time. Indeed, President Erdogan congratulated the victor after the landslide saw Imamoglu defeat ex-PM Yildirim by whopping 800k votes. Usd/Try is hovering towards the bottom of a 5.7085-8200, with additional support for the Lira from an improvement in Turkish manufacturing sentiment.

RBA Governor Lowe said risks to global economy are tilted to the downside and that it is legitimate to question how effective monetary easing would be globally, while he also suggested that if everyone is easing, the impact on exchange rates is offset. Lowe added that more infrastructure investment would benefit the Australian economy and that government can borrow at historic lows but it must be projects that can make a return, while other Twitter sources reported that Lowe suggested it is unclear what further impact easing could have on the economy. (Newswires/Twitter)

Westpac revised its RBA cut call to July (Prev. August). (Newswires)

Turkish opposition candidate Imamoglu beat former PM and Erdogan ally Yildirim in the rerun of the Istanbul mayoral election. (Newswires)

RBI confirms that Deputy Governor Acharya submitted his resignation a few weeks ago, citing personal reasons. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Bunds are nudging new Eurex highs after easing back in wake of the Ifo survey that held up better than anticipated in 2 out of the 3 metrics, and with renewed buying interest perhaps prompted by a downturn in BTPs and other peripheral bonds. The 10 year German benchmark just traded at 172.52 (+45 ticks vs -5 ticks), and from a chart perspective the next upside objective is 172.57, before 172.65-70 and the 172.88 contract peak. Meanwhile, Gilts remain just shy of their Liffe best for the day so far amidst a blank UK agenda, but US Treasuries are firmer and the curve somewhat flatter ahead of a relatively light slate with just a couple of survey releases and a sole Fed speaker. Note, USTs may already be making room for this week’s auctions that are weighted towards the short end and total Usd113 bn (via 2s, 5s and 7s).

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures have retreated from highs in recent trade as the upside momentum seen in the complex somewhat wanes ahead of this week’s US-Sino meeting. Over the weekend, US President Trump announced the intention of further tariffs on Iran to stem the country’s nuclear developments, although Russia’s Deputy Foreign Minister noted that the US is deliberately raising tensions with Iran and stated that Moscow and allies will counteract US sanctions on Tehran. WTI futures hover around USD 58/bbl (having hit an intraday high of USD 58.20/bbl) whilst its Brent counterpart trades just below the USD 65.50/bbl mark and closer to the bottom of today’s range. Elsewhere, gold prices hover around 6yr highs amid dovish central banks and rising tensions in the Middle East. Meanwhile, copper prices declined back below the USD 2.7/lb level as the red metal side-lines strikes at Chile's Chuquicamata copper mine and takes the cue from the subdued risk tone heading into the G20 summit. Finally, Chinese Rebar steel traded near eight-year highs as demand picks up while output curbs have been extended in an attempt to reduce air pollution.

At least 8 people were killed after an oil pipeline exploded in the southeast of Nigeria. (Newswires)

Iranian Oil Minister has denied reports which state that Iran's oil exports have recently fallen. (Newswires)

Kazakh Energy Minister is comfortable with oil in the range of USD 60-70/bbl, prices over USD 70/bbl will encourage higher US production, Kashagan oil field production to be increased by 20k BPD to 420kBPD by year-end. (Newswires)

Azeri Energy Minister states that he supports a rollover of the current oil output pact. (Newswires)

subject: Saudi Minister Jubeir notes that there will be more Iranian sanctions if Tehran continues with its aggressive policies, "it will pay the price"
Nordea trade recommendation - long Eur/Nok at market (ca 9.6475), targeting 9.8600 and stop at 9.6200

24th June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week somewhat choppy with participants tentative ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting at the G20 this week and following the mild pullback last Friday on Wall St where all majors ended slightly lower on the day, but still notched gains of more than 2% for the week. ASX 200 (-0.1%) was led lower by underperformance in Consumer Staples as Metcash shares dropped nearly 10% following disappointing FY results and as comments from RBA Governor Lowe appeared to question the impact easing could have on the economy, while a non-committal tone was seen in the Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) amid a mixed currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were indecisive after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and as global markets await the latest developments in the trade war saga including the Trump-Xi showdown this week, while the US recently added 5 Chinese entities to its blacklist barring them from buying US parts without government approval.

FTSE 100

Lloyds (LLOY LN) – Co. have frozen 8k offshore banking accounts as part of a money laundering crackdown after asking them for three years to prove their identities. (FT)

British American Tobacco (BATS LN)/ Imperial Brands (IMB LN) – US listed Philip Morris (PM) is planning to open four IQOS stores in an attempt to drive heated tobacco and vape sales. (Times)

BT (BT/A LN) – Co’s CEO Jansen has purchased 1.5mln of the Co’s share, valued at approximately GBP 3mln. (FT)

Gambling names – UK Gambling Commission has called for betting companies to fund gambling addiction treatments through the NHS. The tax on the gambling names seem to be moving closer after the head of the NHS said that voluntary donations are not raising enough money, according to the Times. (Times)

Energy Names – The UK has obtained more energy from zero-carbon sources than fossil fuels for the first 5-months of the year. (Newswires/BBC)

Mobile operators – Leader of a cross-party group of MPs stated that mobile operations should face scrutiny over High Court claims of attempted price fixing and collusion. (Telegraph)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Daimler (DAI GY) – Co. cut its 2019 outlook, citing costs in regard to the diesel emission scandal. Co. said it’s numbers will be hit by “a high three-digit million” charge and now expects its EBIT to be similar to last year’s level vs. Prev. guidance of “slightly higher” EBIT. The new outlook is EUR 500mln below current analysts consensus for 2019, according to data by S&P Global Market Intelligence. (FT/Newswires) For reference, this is Co’s third profit warning in the last 12 months. Separately, German Transportation Minister stated that Co. must recall 60k Mercedes diesel cars in Germany after they were found to be fitted with software aimed at distorting emission tests. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Fed officials have asked senior executives at the Co. to explain ‘bad bank’ proposals, in order to explain concerns regarding a potential significant impact to the Co’s US operations. The size of such a scheme is still being decided, but executives are reportedly considering placing up to EUR 50bln of assets into it. (FT)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Metro AG (B4B GY) – Co. has rejected a EUR 5.8bln takeover offer stating that it ‘substantially undervalues’ the Co. Rejection follows EP Global Commerce stating they would offer EUR 16.00 for each share they do not currently control. (FT)

Morphosys (MOR GY) – Co. met primary endpoint for L-MIND treatment combination. (Newswires)

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – Co. plans to pay a dividend of 20-40% of the group’s net profits vs. prior policy stipulated pay-out of 10-25% of group EBIT. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

RWE (RWE GY) DOWNGRADED TO REDUCE FROM HOLD AT HSBC

METRO (B4B GY) UPGRADED TO MARKET PERFORM FROM UNDERPERFORM AT BERNSTEIN

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. are closing their UK subsidiary GPT Special Project Management, following several years of investigation regarding bribery allegations for a Saudi Arabian military contract. (Guardian)

Carrefour (CA FP) – Co. has agreed to sell 80% of its Chinese operations for EUR 620mln in cash to Suning.com. (Newswires)

Renault (RNO FP) – Co. is hoping to resume dialogue with Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) on a merger soon, according to reports. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Alstom (ALO FP) – Co. notes that the FY 19/20 FY will have sales and margin growth lower than the average objectives set in its strategy plan. Co. targets mid-term adj. EBIT at around 9%, annual sales growth of around 5% and note that FY 19 is to be a year of “stabilisation of growth”. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

VALEO (FR FP) REITERATED OVERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN CHASE

NATIXIS (KN FP) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN CHASE

PAN EUROPE

Banking names - Fed stress test results on Friday showed all banks exceeded minimum capital requirements and at strong levels that would allow them to remain above minimum required level after being tested against a severe hypothetical recession scenario. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

TOD’S (TOD IM) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT CREDIT SUISSE

SMI

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

JULIUS BAER (BAER SW) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM AT RBC

SCANDINAVIA 

BROKER MOVES

US

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 24th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equities began the week somewhat choppy with participants tentative ahead of the Trump-Xi G20 meeting
  • Conservative Party is reportedly making plans that would permit the next PM to hold off from putting their Brexit plans to Parliament until Autumn
  • US President Trump said he has no pre-conditions for talks with Iran. However, the US will be moving ahead with sanctions on the nation
  • Turkish opposition candidate Imamoglu beat former PM and Erdogan ally Yildirim in the rerun of the Istanbul mayoral election
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German IFO, NZ Trade, ECB’s Lautenschlager, Fed’s Harker

 

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week somewhat choppy with participants tentative ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting at the G20 this week and following the mild pullback last Friday on Wall St where all majors ended slightly lower on the day, but still notched gains of more than 2% for the week. ASX 200 (-0.1%) was led lower by underperformance in Consumer Staples and as comments from RBA Governor Lowe appeared to question the impact easing could have on the economy, while a non-committal tone was seen in the Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) amid a mixed currency. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) were indecisive after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and as global markets await the latest developments in the trade war saga including the Trump-Xi showdown this week, while the US recently added 5 Chinese entities to its blacklist barring them from buying US parts without government approval. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued with after recent similar moves in T-notes and as yields bounced back from multi-year lows, while demand was also dampened after stocks in Tokyo pared opening weakness and amid the absence of the BoJ in the market.  

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8503 (Prev. 6.8472)

China Vice Commerce Minister Wang Shouwen said China and US trade teams are having discussions, while he added that both sides should make compromises and hopes G20 sends a clear signal on fighting against trade protectionism. (Newswires)

China Assistant Foreign Minister Zhang Jun said the world economy faces increasing risks and the international community recognizes harm from protectionism, while he added that G20 should ensure unity and cooperation but also stated that China will safeguard its fundamental interests and will not allow anyone to interfere with its internal affairs no matter what forum. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor said China is concerned about fairness of the trade deal and the most important part is the US side must remove all newly imposed tariffs since the trade war or else China won't accept a deal. (Twitter)

 

UK/EU

Conservative Party is reportedly making plans that would permit the next PM to hold off from putting their Brexit plans to Parliament until Autumn which could limit the time to reach a deal to just over 3 weeks before October 31st. (Independent)

Conservative leadership hopeful Hunt has accused Boris Johnson of being a coward for avoiding public scrutiny as pressure mounts on the Tory frontrunner to address the row with his girlfriend that led to police being called. (Times)

EY ITEM Club forecasts 2019 UK GDP growth at 1.3% Y/Y, sees consumer spending growth at 1.6% which is the slowest since 2013. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed Spain at A-; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

DXY sits above 96.00 following last week’s FOMC-induced losses and another bout of weak PMI data. This benefitted its major counterparts with EUR/USD at its strongest levels in 3 months and closer to 1.1400 where there is around EUR 1.5bln of option expiries at 1.1395-1.1400 for today’s New York cut, while GBP/USD was steady circa 1.2750. Price action in USD/JPY and JPY-crosses largely reflected their individual base currencies, and antipodeans were firmer overnight with AUD/USD underpinned after comments from RBA Governor Lowe who suggested it was legitimate to question how effective monetary easing would be globally. NZD/USD was marginally higher and attempted to reclaim 0.6600 ahead of this week’s RBNZ meeting where markets are pointing to a less than a 29% chance of a cut although August is seen as priced in, while TRY was another notable gainer after the Turkey opposition candidate Imamoglu beat former PM and Erdogan ally Yildirim in the rerun of the Istanbul mayoral election which President Erdogan congratulated him on.

 

RBA Governor Lowe said risks to global economy are tilted to the downside and that it is legitimate to question how effective monetary easing would be globally, while he also suggested that if everyone is easing, the impact on exchange rates is offset. Lowe added that more infrastructure investment would benefit the Australian economy and that government can borrow at historic lows but it must be projects that can make a return, while other Twitter sources reported that Lowe suggested it is unclear what further impact easing could have on the economy. (Newswires/Twitter)

 

Turkish opposition candidate Imamoglu beat former PM and Erdogan ally Yildirim in the rerun of the Istanbul mayoral election. (Newswires) 

COMMODITIES

WTI crude prices extended on recent gains after having notched its best weekly performance since Dec’16 due to the weaker USD and ongoing geopolitical tensions concerning Iran. Furthermore, the Baker Hughes rig count also showed a decline in total US rigs despite oil drillers increasing rigs for the 1st time in 3 weeks and prices now eye a retest of resistance ahead of USD 58.00/bbl. Gold was marginally higher due to a softer greenback and as USD 1400/oz acts as base for prices, copper traded sideways amid the tentative risk tone and early weakness in Dalian iron ore prices which slumped around 3% shortly after the open. 

 

Baker Hughes (June 21): oil rigs +1 at 789, gas rigs -4 at 177, total US rigs -2 at 967. (Newswires)

 

At least 8 people were killed after an oil pipeline exploded in the southeast of Nigeria. (Newswires)

 

India's Oil Minister spoke to Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih and expressed concern on rising prices after the tanker attacks in the Strait of Hormuz and wants Saudi Arabia to play an active role in OPEC+ to keep oil prices at a reasonable level. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

US President Trump said he has no pre-conditions for talks with Iran and that he would be willing to meet with the Ayatollah or President but added that ballistic missiles would have to be considered in a deal. However, US President Trump also said that they are moving ahead with additional sanctions on Iran aimed at preventing it from getting a nuclear weapon and that military action is still on the table, while other reports also noted the White House is pressing for additional options including in cyberspace and other additional clandestine plans to counter Iranian aggression in the Persian Gulf. (Newswires/NYTimes)

US President Trump administration’s Middle East peace plan reportedly proposes USD 50bln investment in Palestinian territories, Egypt, Jordan and Lebanon. In related news, US President Trump spoke with the Saudi Crown Prince bin Salman on Middle East stability as well as the oil market. (Newswires)

Iran said it believes EU lacks the will to salvage the multinational 2015 nuclear deal, while its Deputy Foreign Minister said the decision to decrease its commitment to nuclear deal is a national decision and irreversible as long as its demands are not met. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia’s Abha civilian airport located in the south of the country was attacked by Yemen's Houthi rebels which killed one person and wounded seven others, while the Arab Coalition stated that the attack by the Iranian-backed terrorist Houthi militia and the targeting of civilians is a brutal terrorist act. (Newswires0

North Korea confirmed that its leader Kim received a letter from US President Trump in which the contents of the letter were described as excellent. (Newswires)

 

US

 

Treasuries gave back some of the geopolitically induced gains seen on Thursday, with yields settling 5-7bps higher across the curve; this added some daylight between the 10-year yield and the 2% handle (which was breached on Thursday for the first time since Nov’2016). However, geopolitical analysts have warned that the tensions are far from over, and even though Trump has reached out to Iranian leaders for unconditional talks, military options remain. This week’s sales of 2s, 5s and 7s will be eyed, with desks suggesting that the dovish Fed pricing could support the complex, like we saw in the 3s/10s/30s auctions recently, especially so amid the geopolitical background. US T-notes (U9) settled 17+ lower at 127-16+.

Fed's Brainard (voter, dove) said risk management argues for a lower rate path when risks shift to the downside and that she has seen downside risks in recent weeks. Brainard also said that inflation indicators have been disappointing making it important to sustain momentum, while she added that US economy remains solid and that rates will likely remain low in the future. (Newswires)

Fed stress test results on Friday showed all banks exceeded minimum capital requirements and at strong levels that would allow them to remain above minimum required level after being tested against a severe hypothetical recession scenario. (Newswires)

Outgoing CEA Chair Hassett said the market is now expecting what US President Trump has been expecting for months; that global economy is much softer than what we thought 8-9 months ago. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia begins the week somewhat mixed as participants await the Trump-Xi showdown at the G20
content:
Asia equity markets begin the week somewhat choppy with participants tentative ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting at the G20 this week and following the mild pullback last Friday on Wall St where all majors ended slightly lower on the day, but still notched gains of more than 2% for the week. ASX 200 (-0.2%) is led lower by underperformance in Consumer Staples as Metcash shares drop more than 9% following disappointing FY results and as comments from RBA Governor Lowe appear to question the impact easing could have on the economy, while a non-committal tone was seen in the Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) amid a mixed currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were indecisive after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and as global markets await the latest developments in the trade war saga including the Trump-Xi showdown this week, while the US recently added 5 Chinese entities to its blacklist barring them from buying US parts without government approval.

In FX markets, the DXY remains subdued and approaches the 96.00 level to the downside following last week’s FOMC-induced losses and which was also not helped by another batch of weak PMI data. This has benefitted its major counterparts with EUR/USD at its strongest levels in 3 months and closer to the 1.1400 handle where there is around EUR 1.5bln of option expiries at 1.1395-1.1400 for today’s New York cut, while GBP/USD is steady circa 1.2750. Elsewhere, price action in USD/JPY and JPY-crosses largely reflect their individual base currencies, and antipodeans are firmer overnight with AUD/USD underpinned after comments from RBA Governor Lowe who suggested it was legitimate to question how effective monetary easing would be globally and that if everyone is easing, the impact on exchange rates is offset. NZD/USD is marginally higher and attempts to reclaim the 0.6600 handle ahead of this week’s RBNZ meeting where markets are pointing to less than a 32% chance of a cut although August is seen as priced in, while TRY was another notable gainer after the Turkey opposition candidate Imamoglu beat former PM and Erdogan ally Yildirim in the rerun of the Istanbul mayoral election which President Erdogan congratulated him on.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are subdued with prices marginally lower after recent similar moves in T-notes and as yields bounce back from multi-year lows, while demand is also dampened after stocks in Tokyo pared opening weakness and amid the absence of the BoJ in the market.
